report_title: Oil & Gas Field Services in the US
executive_summary: The oil and gas field services industry has faced declines over the current period due to the COVID-19 pandemic leading to considerable declines in oil and gas production and the need for services. However, as production ramped up in 2022 to take advantage of favorable pricing from Russia's invasion of Ukraine, providers enjoyed strong growth but did not recover from pandemic declines. Revenue has fallen at a 5.0% CAGR to $95.4 billion in 2023 with a 4.2% decrease, while profit is set to climb to 20.4%. The adoption of efficient enhanced oil recovery techniques initially benefitted providers but has decreased rig demand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The widespread adoption of hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling has contributed to a rapid outburst of crude oil and natural gas availability since the early 2000s. More drilling and support services have been deployed to help exploration and production companies find and extract natural resources. The largest deposit of shale oil was just recently discovered in the Wolfcamp formation within the Permian Basin.

Over the outlook period, oil and gas field services providers will enjoy modest growth. Natural gas and crude oil prices will become more stable over the next five years, enabling an increased level of investment in the industry and providing a boost to oil and gas field services providers. However, increased investment in renewable energy will threaten field service providers over the outlook period. Nonetheless, US oil and gas producers looking to keep production strong to export energy will benefit oil and gas field services providers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Oil and gas prices are poised to fall
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Oil and gas prices will be more stable over the next five years than during the COVID-19 pandemic, benefiting field services providers, though production may dip.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Fossil fuels face pressure from renewables
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Inflation Reduction Act provides credits for renewable investments, threatening oil and gas producers and field services providers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Natural gas production will lead to gains
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Natural gas will remain a key energy source, promoting growth for field services providers, with exports also driving gains.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Trade to promote growth over the outlook
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the trade-weighted index falls, making exports more appealing, oil and gas exports comprising a large percentage will increase need for field services.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry provide support services on a fee or contract basis to companies involved in oil and gas extraction, mining and quarrying. Industry operators may also provide services such as drilling, taking core samples and making geological observations at prospective work sites.

opportunities: US oil and gas production index

key_trends: Technological growth has led to declines as efficient enhanced oil recovery techniques decreased needed rigs.
Oil and gas field services providers to enjoy modest growth as US producers increase energy exports.
Field service providers face very high regulation and little assistance.
Oil and gas prices significantly impact demand for field services.
Oil extractors decreased dependence on field services due to efficient drilling techniques.
Demand for gas services experienced more upside as gas production ramped up.
Texas is a major hub for field services companies supporting oil and gas production.
The Gulf of Mexico has a high concentration of larger offshore field services operators.
Contracts are largely awarded via competitive bidding based on price and quality.
The offshore drilling segment is less competitive than onshore due to fewer operators.
Major M&A includes Schlumberger acquiring Smith and GE's Baker Hughes deal.
COVID-19 severely impacted even largest providers like Schlumberger and Halliburton.
Profit climbed as contract prices followed rising oil and gas prices despite revenue declines.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Crude oil producers explore and develop oil field properties.
Natural gas producers explore and develop gas fields. Hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling have made this energy much more attainable and less expensive.
Gold, silver, iron, nickel and copper mines all require mining support services.
Coal mines require mining support services. Coal production has fallen over the current period as the US continues to phase out its use.
Stone, sand and gravel quarries all require mining support services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Natural gas overtook coal as the leading source of electric power in the United States in 2016
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Natural gas is more affordable and cleaner than coal, making it an excellent energy source to use as the United States develops its renewable energy infrastructure.

business_locations.location_description: Similar to the Southwest, the concentration of businesses in the Southeast reflects the significant oil and gas output in the area as a whole and in Louisiana in particular.
The West region has the second highest percentage of establishments at 24.0%, higher than its population percentage of 19.5%.

The Southwest dominates mining activity in the US. Texas alone holds more establishments than any region other than the Southwest. This region's importance to the industry is due primarily to its abundant reserves of oil and gas in the Haynesville, Eagle Ford and Permian shale plays.
The Plains region has a higher percentage of establishments (9.2%) compared to its population percentage (6.8%).
The Mid-Atlantic region has a lower percentage of establishments (9.4%) compared to its population percentage (14.1%).
The Great Lakes region has a lower percentage of establishments (9.0%) compared to its population percentage (14.9%).

The Rocky Mountains ranks third for business concentration. Colorado has the largest concentration of oil and gas field services establishments within the region. The Niobrara-DJ Basin is a rich oil and gas play located mostly between Colorado and Wyoming.
The New England region has the lowest percentage of establishments at 2.1%, while its population percentage is 4.5%.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is responsible for the protection of human health and the environment. The EPA provides technical assistance and environmental surveillance. Oil and gas companies are required to comply with EPA regulations including the Clean Air Act; Clean Water Act; Toxic Substances Control Act; Resource Conservation and Recovery Act; Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act; Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act; and Endangered Species Act.

The Bureau of Land Management (BLM)'s goal is to sustain the health, diversity and productivity of public land for use and enjoyment of current and future generations. This federal agency oversees 245.0 million acres of surface land and 700.0 million acres of subsurface mineral estate. The BLM derives its authority from the Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 and the Naval Petroleum Reserves Production Act of 1976.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) was created with the passage of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. OSHA's mission is to ensure safe and healthful working conditions by setting and enforcing standards and providing training, education and assistance. Respiratory protection, duty to have fall protection, explosives and blasting agents and wiring design and protection are the most common OSHA citations given to mining support services.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Capital intensive equipment and human capital requirements
barriers_points.barrier_description: Oil and gas field services providers rely on large-scale equipment like drilling rigs that can be extremely capital intensive. They also rely extensively on human capital to run machinery and manage operations.

basis_points.basis_description: Contracts secured by companies are largely awarded on a competitive bid basis. Price competition is often the primary factor in determining which contractor is awarded a contract, although quality of service, operational and safety performance are also factors.

The offshore drilling services segment is characterized by a small number of companies. Within land drilling, the arena is substantially more competitive due to a greater number of operators and rigs competing for contracts.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low concentration in onshore, higher in offshore
concentration_points.concentration_description: Concentration is particularly low among companies that provide support services for oil drilling and gas extraction on land, as providing these services has fewer barriers than offshore drilling services. Concentration is higher in the offshore oil and gas extraction services segment because these services have greater capital requirements and fewer support companies serving these operations.

Consolidation has increased in recent years as many oil and gas field services providers have succumbed to volatile economic pressures, which were exacerbated following the outbreak of COVID-19. Mergers and acquisitions have contributed to a declining number of service providers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Costs Climb Despite Employment Plummeting
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Oil and gas field service providers heavily rely on oilfield workers, petroleum and chemical engineers, research scientists, mineral ore prospectors, drilling specialists and other highly skilled professionals. Consequently, wages are a major component of field service providers' cost structure and account for an estimated 28.9% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Have Fallen as Growth Slowed
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are required for drilling, acidizing, cementing and other services provided by this industry. Oil and gas field service providers frequently purchase parts for drill rigs, cement for wells, chemical compounds and other

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Oil and gas field services providers rely on large-scale equipment
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Oil and gas field services providers rely on large-scale equipment, like land-based and offshore drilling rigs of various sizes, that can be extremely capital intensive.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Service providers also rely extensively on human capital
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: However, service providers also rely extensively on human capital to run machinery and manage operations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies entering the industry
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: High concentration of technologies in the industry
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.
The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Supply and Demand of Fossil Fuels Impact Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue is directly linked to the level of fossil fuel exploration and production in the United States. As upstream oil and gas companies look to produce more oil, they require a greater amount of geological, drilling and operational support services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Demand for mining support services tumbled during COVID-19 pandemic
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for mining support services tumbled when global energy consumption fell during the COVID-19 pandemic. Support services have come back in demand as oil and gas production is ramped back up.

Oil prices can fluctuate markedly based on the balance between demand and supply and short-term mismatches between these two guiding forces. Changes in the price of oil and can also influence demand for mining support services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue fell considerably in 2020 due to COVID-19 pandemic
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue fell considerably in 2020 when socioeconomic restrictions hamstrung demand for energy during the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue surged in 2022 as the world prices of oil and gas improved markedly and production of fossil fuels ramped back up.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Increased efficiencies have hindered the need for oil drilling services
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The number of new wells being drilling is falling since hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling have made operational wells extremely productive. So, despite climbing production from oil producers, these segments have dipped as a share of revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Gas well support services have shown the most upside potential
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Growing demand for natural gas as an energy source in the United States has made this segment perform comparatively better than all other industry-related services. Natural gas production has surged in recent years as US producers looked to take advantage of the favorable price environment amid supply chain woes.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Demand for gas drilling services grows second fastest
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Natural gas overtook coal as the leading source of electric power in the United States in 2016. Natural gas is more affordable and cleaner than coal, making it an excellent energy source to use as the United States develops its renewable energy infrastructure. Climbing natural gas production and exports has bolstered this segment.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: All other mining support services (except oil and gas) remain flat
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: All other mining support services include strip mining, overburden stripping, sinking shafts, prospect and drilling services and blasting. These services also include exploration, open pit mining or quarrying, prospect and test drilling services, overburden stripping and sinking shafts.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports in the oil and gas extraction industry affects demands for services of the operators in this industry. However, as the US has become more energy independent over the past decade, domestic operators have benefitted.

FAQs.question: Has competition from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry operate worldwide and competition for specialized and highly complex projects is limited.

FAQs.question: Has your company dealt with volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Industry revenue moves in line with trends in commodity prices especially price of crude oil and natural gas. During the period, these commodities have seen very high levels of price volatility, which have generally negatively impacted operators.

FAQs.question: Does your company perform research and development to keep up with the latest extraction techniques?
FAQs.answer: Research and Development expenditures are very high in the industry as operators constantly need to innovate to keep up with the demands of oil and gas extractors.

FAQs.question: How is your company using new technology, such as new drilling techniques?
FAQs.answer: Large operators have hundreds of patents and constantly provide innovative techniques for its customers to utilize.

FAQs.question: What technology do you invest in to establish an edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Large operators dominate new technological innovation in this industry.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted your company's profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulation has increased in the industry over the past five years. Due to the new presidential administration, regulations for operators is expected to increase as the press towards renewable energy continues to accelerate.

FAQs.question: How have recent changes to environmental standards impacted your company's operations?
FAQs.answer: Environmental regulation varies on state policies and has increased over the past five years. The current presidential administration is expected to increase regulations on the industry due to its advocacy of green policies.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins have been volatile over the past five years as crude oil prices have swung wildly. The price declines during the pandemic have caused further stress to operators, but recovered beginning in 2021.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past year?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins vary based on the project that the company undertakes and has remained under pressure over the past five years.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation with clients? How could you improve your word-of-mouth reputation?
FAQs.answer: Having a high prior success rate (including completed prior contracts). Companies providing oil and gas field support services compete on the basis of reputation as well as price.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a reputation for good work practices? How could you increase efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Use of most efficient work practices. Since companies hire out rigs and crews on an agreed day-rate basis, efficient work practices are needed to ensure that costs do not outstrip revenue.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers? Have you had to drop prices over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Ensuring pricing policy is appropriate. The price companies charge, usually through day rates, must be competitive enough to win contracts and adjusted accordingly to demand.

FAQs.question: How has the price of oil influenced demand for your services? Have you been able to maintain growth as prices dropped during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Rising crude oil prices typically lead to increased demand for oil drilling and extraction. As demand increases, crude oil extractors contract out support services to the Oil and Gas Field Services industry. The pandemic caused extreme levels of price volatility for crude oil, with the front-month contract even becoming negative in the spring of 2020.

FAQs.question: With which regulatory bodies do you deal with the most? How has regulation affected your operations?
FAQs.answer: The industry is subject to a wide range of regulations regarding the location of drill rigs and risks associated with drilling and hydraulic-fracturing operations.

FAQs.question: Does your company monitor volumes of oil and gas produced in the United States? How have recent trends affected your company?
FAQs.answer: The US oil and gas production index measures annual fluctuations in oil and gas production. According to the EIA, the industry's daily production of crude has fallen from its peak of 13,100 barrels in March 2020 to 10,000 barrels per day in February 2021. This decline in production has caused declines in demand for industry services.
